message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest exercise-induced muscle fatigue, which can be caused by a glycogen storage disorder. The increased serum ammonia levels indicate impaired energy metabolism, which is consistent with subsarcolemmal acid-Schiff-positive deposits seen in glycogen storage disorders. CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration is seen in autoimmune myositis, endomysial fibrosis with absent dystrophin is seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy, and intermyofibrillar proliferation of mitochondria is seen in mitochondrial myopathies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are suggestive of exercise-induced muscle cramps, which might be caused by subsarcolemmal acid–Schiff-positive deposits. The increase in serum ammonia levels during exercise also suggests a metabolic disorder. Intrafascicular CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration is seen in cases of polymyositis and necrotizing myopathy, not in exercise-induced muscle cramps. Endomysial fibrosis with absent dystrophin is seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Intermyofibrillar proliferation of mitochondria is seen in cases of mitochondrial myopathies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of fatigue and weakness after exertion, along with leg cramps and relief with rest, suggest a muscular disorder. The increase in serum ammonia levels during exercise suggests a problem with the urea cycle or liver metabolism. Option D is the most likely as it suggests a glycogen storage disease like McArdle's disease, which would lead to exercise intolerance and an increase in serum ammonia levels during exercise. Intrafascicular CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration suggests an autoimmune myositis, endomysial fibrosis with absent dystrophin suggests Duchenne muscular dystrophy, and intermyofibrillar proliferation of mitochondria suggests mitochondrial myopathy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the blood in urine suggest that the patient may have exercise-induced rhabdomyolysis. The blood pressure cuff test helps to diagnose the condition, which is characterized by an increase in serum ammonia levels and stable venous lactate levels. Subsarcolemmal acid–Schiff-positive deposits are a common finding in rhabdomyolysis biopsies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the blood in urine suggest the patient may have exercise-induced rhabdomyolysis. The test with the blood pressure cuff inflated helps confirm the diagnosis. Among the options, subsarcolemmal acid-Schiff-positive deposits are commonly seen in patients with mitochondrial myopathies, which can cause exercise intolerance and muscle weakness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of chronic fatigue and muscle weakness after exertion, along with the presence of blood in urine suggests exercise-induced rhabdomyolysis. The fact that ammonia levels increase over time and lactate levels remain stable suggests the muscle is unable to properly utilize oxygen during exercise, leading to anaerobic metabolism and the accumulation of byproducts such as ammonia. This suggests that the biopsy would most likely show subsarcolemmal acid-Schiff-positive deposits, which are indicative of mitochondrial myopathies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the blood test results suggest exercise-induced compartment syndrome or exertional rhabdomyolysis. The biopsy findings consistent with exertional rhabdomyolysis include subsarcolemmal acid-Schiff-positive deposits, indicating the accumulation of glycogen within the subsarcolemmal mitochondria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of fatigue and weakness after exertion with relief by rest suggest a metabolic myopathy. The increasing serum ammonia levels with stable lactate suggests a deficiency in the urea cycle enzyme arginase, leading to hyperammonemia. The most likely diagnosis is McArdle disease, which is characterized by subsarcolemmal acid-Schiff-positive deposits in muscle biopsies.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a metabolic myopathy, and the continuous arm exercise test is consistent with McArdle disease, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme myophosphorylase. A biopsy of the right gastrocnemius muscle in McArdle disease will show subsarcolemmal acid-Schiff-positive deposits, which represent glycogen accumulation. The other options are associated with different types of muscle disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the test results suggest that the patient may have exercise-induced compartment syndrome or McArdle disease. Subsarcolemmal acid-Schiff-positive deposits are most likely to be seen in a biopsy of the muscle of a patient with McArdle disease. Intrafascicular CD8+ lymphocytic infiltration is associated with inclusion body myositis. Endomysial fibrosis with absent dystrophin is seen in Duchenne muscular dystrophy. Intermyofibrillar proliferation of mitochondria is seen in mitochondrial myopathy.
